column2: TEHRAN, Iran (AP) â€” During its 1979 Islamic Revolution, Iran embraced the protest cry of â€œneither East nor West,â€ rejecting both the U.S. and the Soviet Union, then locked in the Cold War. The phrase to this day hangs over the doors of Iranâ€™s Foreign Ministry. Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraine, however, has exposed just how much Tehran has tilted toward Moscow in recent years as the collapse of its nuclear deal with world powers stoked decades-old, hard-line anger at America. Members of Iranâ€™s paramilitary Revolutionary Guard train on Russian surface-to-air missile systems and aircraft. Hard-line President Ebrahim Raisi visited Russian President Vladimir Putin on one of his first trips abroad. The war also exposes deeper fault lines even within Iranâ€™s domestic politics. Among ordinary Iranians, there is a great deal of sympathy for Ukraine, a nation that staged a pro-democracy â€œOrange Revolutionâ€ similar to the â€œGreen Revolutionâ€ that shook Iran more than a decade ago but was forcefully put down. Iranâ€™s historic enmity with Russia has combined with a wider feeling among some that backing Moscow betrays the Islamic Republicâ€™s often-stated message that it stands against the worldâ€™s major powers. â€œWe have to help oppressed people of Ukraine as we do support people of Palestine and Yemen simply because they are targeted by powers,â€ said Zohreh Ahmadi, a mother of two in downtown Tehranâ€™s Sarcheshmeh neighborhood. â€œA bullying power is killing children and women in Ukraine.â€ Iran's state-controlled television network, whose English-language service Press TV describes itself as â€œthe voice of the voiceless," hews close to Russian talking points. It used Moscow's euphemistic term â€œspecial operationâ€ to describe the war's early days. Stories referencing the killings of civilians in Bucha by Russian forces include headlines falsely describing it as a â€œfake attackâ€ or â€œprovocationâ€ on Press TV's website. Part of the Iranian government's anger at Ukraine likely stems from the aftermath of the Guard's 2020 shooting down of an Ukrainian airliner, which killed 176 people on board. Tehran denied for days it shot down the plane before saying troops made a mistake after Iran fired ballistic missiles at U.S. forces in Iraq in response for the killing of a top general. Ukraineâ€™s criticism of Iran grew more direct as time went on. Thatâ€™s something Tehranâ€™s Friday prayer leader, Kazem Sedighi, mentioned in a March sermon after Russia began its war on Ukraine. â€œIn the case of the airplane, Ukraine misbehaved against us and misused it in support to the U.S.,â€ Sedighi said. He also engaged in the â€œwhataboutismâ€ common in both Iranian and Russian state media â€” bringing up a separate topic to charge hypocrisy while deflecting the issue at hand. â€œWars claim the lives of innocent people in Yemen and Syria but there is huge propaganda over Ukraine and this is racism,â€ Sedighi said. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who has final say on all matters of state, said his nation opposed â€œwar and destructionâ€ while blaming America for the conflict. He also brought up a longtime suspicion that he shares with Putin â€” that the U.S., rather than ordinary citizens, fuels what he described as the â€œcolor coupsâ€ that back democracy. For Khamenei, it is memory of the Green Movement protests that followed Iran's disputed 2009 presidential election that directly challenged the theocracy he leads. Iran's security services used violence and mass arrests to put down the demonstrations. But unrest has re-emerged in recent years over economic issues. For Putin, it is Ukraine's 2004 Orange Revolution and its later Maidan protest movement that dislodged the Kremlin-leaning politician Viktor Yanukovych. But others from within Iranâ€™s Shiite theocracy have raised concerns about Tehranâ€™s stance on the war. Mohsen Aminzadeh, a former deputy foreign minister under reformist President Mohammad Khatami who was later imprisoned after the disputed 2009 election, went as far as to call Iranâ€™s position â€œvery badâ€ in a recent interview. â€œIt was possibly the worst, the most passive stance of Iranâ€™s diplomacy since 1979,â€ Aminzadeh recently told the monthly magazine Ayandeh Negar. On the streets of Tehran recently, 17 people were willing to speak to an Associated Press journalist about the war, with others declining. Of them, 12 supported Ukraine, three reiterated Iranâ€™s official stance and two supported Russia. â€œI support Ukraine,â€ said Sajjad, a 26-year-old computer programmer. Like others, he spoke on condition he be identified only by his first name for fear of reprisals. â€œRussians are killing innocent people for nothing.
